docs.lead_paragraph: AFTER a weight loss of 200 pounds, the Suffolk County man, who had once weighed more than 500, was left with a pouch of excess skin that itself weighed almost 100 pounds. The man, who asked that his name not be used, complained that the pouch weighed him down so much that it was difficult to walk and impossible to drive because he could not fit behind the steering wheel of his car. After consulting with Dr. Elliot B. Duboys, a plastic surgeon in Woodbury, the man decided to have the pouch surgically removed. But he was shocked, he said, when his managed-care company refused to pay for the procedure because they considered it a cosmetic treatment, and not medically necessary.

headline.main: When Insurers Deem That Surgery Is Purely Cosmetic

docs.lead_paragraph: A state health panel recommended today that Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and lawmakers consider raising the cigarette tax to help New Jersey hospitals cover the cost of free medical treatment for the uninsured. The 36-member advisory committee concluded that the state's $16 billion budget should finance the estimated $400 million annual cost of the free health care, known as the charity care hospital program. The committee is made up of representatives of hospitals, insurers, consumer and business groups and organized labor.

headline.main: Cigarette Tax Urged to Cover Health Costs

docs.lead_paragraph: Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Kansas City is shutting down 11 of its health maintenance organization's 22 clinics, laying off 30 of its 65 primary-care doctors and cutting the salaries of the rest. Humana has dismissed 4 pediatricians and 2 ophthalmologists from among the 89 salaried doctors at its 7 clinics here. St. Luke's Hospital, one of Kansas City's biggest, says that the incomes of its cardiovascular surgeons will drop 40 percent to 50 percent next year.

headline.main: Health-Maintenance Groups Are Seen Entering a Troublesome New Phase

docs.abstract: Managed-care industry, once widely seen as panacea for nation's health care woes, is now entering troublesome new phase: struggling with consequences of its extraordinary expansion this decade, forced in many cases to raise premiums, lay off doctors and close clinics; big insurance companies and big health maintenance organizations find themselves up against two hard-to-reconcile phenomena: seething consumer and political backlash over delays and denial of care on one hand, and their own financial reversals and excess capacity on the other; photo (M)
